Research, Social Design

Pang Jai Fabric Market

{/*

Teammates

Jo Lai, Phoebe Hon, Charisse Kong, Na Leung, Ting Fong Leung, Tze Qiy Leung, Wylie Tam

Chun Wai Lai, Wing Man Lee, Tsz Yan Wong, Brandon Chow, Professor Patricia Choi (Supervisor)

*/}

My Team

Jo Lai, Phoebe Hon, Charisse Kong, Na Leung, Ting Fong Leung, Tze Qiy Leung, Wylie Tam, Chun Wai Lai, Wing Man Lee, Tsz Yan Wong, Brandon Chow, Professor Patricia Choi (Supervisor)

Why did I do this?

In 2023, I studied abroad at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University in hope of learning from and fostering genuine connections with the people of Hong Kong. This was an opportunity to collaborate and design for the Sham Shui Po community.

1-Minute TLDR

{/* Right Column */}

Problem: The cloth vendors of Pang Jai, who were displaced from their original location due to government redevelopment,  are struggling to sustain their enterprises in their new location.‍

Solution: We designed a wayfinding system with directories and storefront signages. Using the fabrics sold at the market, we created tote bags for the store vendors to sell providing both an additional revenue stream and a means of showcasing their products. Furthermore, we organized a community workshop to create an engaging art installation for the market's front entrance, enhancing its visual appeal and drawing in more visitors.‍

How did I get there?: We started off by conducting a site visit and researching about the history of Pang Jai, revealing the challenges faced by displaced cloth vendors. Drawing insights from our research and a relevant case study, we created a strategy that focused on improving the market design and conducting collaborative workshops with people in the district, while preserving its unique cultural heritage. We then drafted proposal and collaborated with the store vendors to create a final design that blends practical interventions with community-driven initiatives to create a vibrant and inclusive space.

My Role

My role for the project to work with my team and the vendors to analyze the pain points and problems with Pang Jai, devise a clear plan through brainstorming session and design a clear wayfinding experience. I'm grateful for the opportunity to work along side a brilliant team of Social, Environmental, Product, and Communication Designers.

{/* that blends practical interventions with community-driven initiatives to create a vibrant and inclusive space */}

The Problem

The cloth vendors of Pang Jai, who were displaced from their original location due to government redevelopment, are struggling to sustain their enterprises in their new location

Pang Jai, formerly located in Yen Chow Street Hawker Bazaar, is a fabric market in Shum Shui Po, Hong Kong, that faced displacement as the government reclaimed the land for public housing development. Despite years of fighting for their rights, the vendors were unable to sustain their businesses after relocation. The remaining 16 cloth vendors have been relocated to the nearby Tung Chau Street Temporary Market, but their businesses have not improved. They reached out to the Hong Kong Polytechnic University seeking assistance to revive and support their struggling enterprises.

History Analysis

{/* Right Column */}

In order to determine the reasons why they were facing the problems and how we should help, we should first learn more about Pang Jai, located in Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong. Today, this area has the highest percentage of eldery.

Pre-Colonial Period: Before 1900s

Sham Shui Po was smalll villiage of mostly rural farmland.

Entrepreneurial Spirit: 1940s - 1960s

After World War 2, Hong Kong experienced a surge in manufacturing and Sham Shui Po became a hub for small-scale markets, including textiles. People continued to flee to Hong Kong in search of safety and better opportunities, due to political unrest. The low cost of living and entrepreneurial spirit of Sham Shui Po attracted immigrants who sought to build businesses and create better lives for themselves and their families. This district became a hub for immigrants to start anew, as unlicensed or licensed cloth vendors are scattered throughout Sham Shui Po, fostering a culture of entrepreneurship among its residents.

The Textile Hub: 1960s - 1990s

Sham Shui Po evolved into the major trading center for fabrics, textiles, and sewing supplies. It became a destination for locals, designers, and manufacturers seeking affordable materials.

A grassroots market composed of local small-scale cloth vendors is commonly referred to as “Pang Jai” in the local community. During its peak, it had a total of 192 stalls.

Relocation: 2013-2017

The government confirmed the alteration works of the Pang Jai site to build public housing, thus requesting the clearance of the present market. In 2015, the remaining hawkers formed their own concern group with volunteers, including town planners, students, community organizers, university teachers, designers, and fashion designers, forming a community planning proposal. In 2016, the government confirmed the market would relocate to the nearby centre. However, the building was originally built as a wet market and in a remote location.

Today: 2017 - Present

The remaining cloth vendors relocated Tung Chau Street Temporary Market to continue their businesses.

District Statistics

To gain insights into potential collaboration partners and understand the district better, we collected current relevant district statistics as references. These statistics will serve as valuable information to inform our decision-making process and help us identify suitable partners for collaboration.

Household Composition, 2023

A nuclear family household refers to a family unit consisting of two parents and their children.Relative households refer to family units that include extended family members beyond the nuclear family.

Floor Area Accommodation

A nuclear family household refers to a family unit consisting of two parents and their children.Relative households refer to family units that include extended family members beyond the nuclear family. Calculated in square meters (m²).

Age Composition

Percent of the population within each age group.

Types of Amenities, Services and Buildings in the Area

Key Groups

Main demographics of people in this region.

Sidewalk Mat Elderly: Near the area, similar to many parts of Hong Kong with an older population, there are elderly people who sell secondhand goods on the street.

Low Income Families: Sham Shui Po is known for its relatively lower cost of living compared to other parts of Hong Kong.

Ethic Minorities: Many minorities like to hang out around the area on weekends.

Middle Income Families: In recent years, Sham Shui Po has gone through changes due to urban development, leading to middle class apartments and condominiums in the region.

Site Analysis

To gain a deeper understanding of Pang Jai and its dynamics, we conducted a site visit and chatted with cloth vendors that were present.

We mapped out what different stalls sold and the names and sections of their stores. Unfortunately many of the vendors were not present, so our oiginal categories were based mostly on speaking to those who were there and what we saw ourselves.

Store Categories

Store Names (Majority are their names in Chinese)

Problem Verification

Through this research and conducting a site visit, it has become apparent that Pang Jai has encountered numerous challenges following their relocation. These factors have significantly impacted the vendors' ability to thrive in their new setting. The current circumstances call for urgent attention and support to address these issues and help Pang Jai regain its momentum and success.

Sparse flow of people: Most people were not aware about Pang Jai, and it was not well known that they had relocated.

Confusing Navigation: In the market, some stall vendors lack clear banners to identify their location, and those that do often have inconsistent and difficult-to-read signage. Furthermore, due to the extensive display of fabric within each stall, vendors often rent multiple stalls and sit among them, making it challenging to identify who to approach when requesting fabric cutting. Banners are placed between stalls rather than on individual stalls to maximize fabric coverage, further complicating navigation.

Vendors sit on the right of the stall, since the stall is filled with fabric.

Store signage example, placed in between stalls, but they only own the left stall.

Store signage example, placed directly above the stall.

Severely restricted business operations: Regulations and economic challenges has lead to limitations on what activities are permitted within the market, building safely regulations, and reduced hours.

Remote location: During our initial site visit, it was apparent that the surrounding area is hostile. The building is difficult to find, as it i placed directly under a bridge. This is further reflected in the poor performance of the nearby Jade Market, established in 2008.

Side view of the market front entrance

Front view of the market front entrance

We intend to utilize the 4Ps in brand strategy to analyze the current situation of Pang Jai. By examining the Product, Price, Promotion, and Place aspects of the market, we can gain valuable insights into its positioning, offerings, pricing, communication, and distribution, aiding us in developing effective strategies for its revitalization.

Product: Pang Jai offers a variety of cloth-related products. It is crucial to assess the quality, range, and uniqueness of the products to ensure they meet the changing demands and preferences of customers.

Price: Considering the challenges faced by Pang Jai, it is essential to evaluate the pricing strategy. This includes examining the affordability and competitiveness of the products to attract customers despite the limitations in the surrounding environment and sparse foot traffic.

Promotion: Pang Jai needs an effective promotional strategy to create awareness and generate interest. Innovative marketing campaigns, workshops, and collaborations with relevant influencers or organizations can help reach a wider audience and revitalize customer engagement

Place: The remote location and subpar surrounding environment have been adversely affected Pang Jai. To overcome these challenges, improving accessibility through transportation links and signage can attract more visitors.

Strategy: The 4 Ps

We intend to utilize the 4 Ps in brand strategy to analyze the current situation of Pang Jai. By examining the Product, Price, Promotion, and Place aspects of the market, we can gain valuable insights into its positioning, offerings, pricing, communication, and distribution, aiding us in developing effective strategies for its revitalization.

Product: Pang Jai offers a variety of cloth-related products. It is crucial to assess the quality, range, and uniqueness of the products to ensure they meet the changing demands and preferences of customers.

Price: Considering the challenges faced by Pang Jai, it is essential to evaluate the pricing strategy. This includes examining the affordability and competitiveness of the products to attract customers despite the limitations in the surrounding environment and sparse foot traffic.

Promotion: Pang Jai needs an effective promotional strategy to create awareness and generate interest. Innovative marketing campaigns, workshops, and collaborations with relevant influencers or organizations can help reach a wider audience and revitalize customer engagement

Place: The remote location and subpar surrounding environment have been adversely affected Pang Jai. To overcome these challenges, improving accessibility through transportation links and signage can attract more visitors.

Initial Proposal

Through our research on the history of Pang Jai, different user groups, and the Grand Bazaar case study, we outlined our next steps moving forward.

  • Design Concept: We needed to determine our brand for Pang Jai.
  • Categorization System: We needed to create away for visitors to efficiently find their goods.
  • Wayfinding System: We needed to create a wayfinding system within the market

After speaking to vendors with this proposal, we can then consider how create a finalized design and consider how we can also involve visitors and different groups in the surrounding area.

Concept 1

Centres on uniqueness, community and indie spirit: To convey the sense of community, we used bright spring palette to show friendliness and connection. Vibrant magenta is used as the main color, which accentuates the unique personality of Pang Jai.

Concept 2

Visuals were inspired by the layering of translucent fabrics. Image references chosen are used to convey that feeling, and simple organic line drawings are used for the local atmosphere.

Concept 3

As the initial idea for concept 3 is to bring and show the new idea of Pang Jai, the design and reference graphics represent new design trends and graphic ideas. Visuals are bright, geometric, and structured to a grid.

Categorization System

To counter the problem of there being no structure of where different kinds of products were sold, we created a categorization system based on the current placement. We proposed a set of icons that reflected each product category.

Wayfinding System

After the initial site visit, it became apparent that there needed to be some sort of signage system to help customers navigate upon walking to the market. We worked together to determine where different signages should be, considering where they would first enter.

Yellow: Entrances

Blue: Individual Store Signage

Orange: Directory Signage

Individual Store Signage

Our idea was that these signs would be placed next to the poles between store blocks, since this is the only space we could use without blocking the products. The signage would show the type of products offered as well.

Option 1

Option 2

Directory Signage

Since during our first site visit many of the vendors were not present, our current directory system may be missing businesses and products. Because of this, we wanted to ask the vendors if this categorization system is correct, and how they would want their store to be shown. We printed a copy of the maps shown above for our proposal.

Initial Feedback from Stall Owners

At this stage, we hoped to show our proposal to different stall owners at Pang Jai to receive their feedback.Mr. Ho, the stall owner who often advised our project, liked the color scheme of concept 1, saying the brighter and more eye-catching the colors the better.

In regards to the activities, Mr. Ho suggested that the contents of the proposed market should be relevant to Pang Jai and promote the purchase of fabric. It was a good idea for Pang Jai to host collection points for online shops, since they already had a store that mainly operated by self-service. Upon the suggestion of making social media for Pang Jai, Mr. Ho stressed the importance of the social media page promoting the entirety of Pang Jai instead of just the individual stores, as they are a collective and should not stoke competition.

For the proposed product designs, Mr. Ho revealed that Pang Jai had already printed promotional t-shirts before, and they still had a lot of it in stock, so perhaps it was not the best idea to make more. However, the tote bag idea was better as they also did this previously and it was a bigger success, and tote bags were practical.

For other decorations, Mr. Ho suggested that we could hang things on the columns in Pang Jai that could easily be taken out. We could integrate the cloth decoration and the historical wall and intersperse them along the metal fencing outside. Our trolley idea was good, but it couldn’t be kept too far outside as it’s more likely to be stolen. The trolley could be an interactive activity, such as letting passersby drop in supportive notes, and it could also act as a platform for promoting design concepts and products.

Him, and many of the other stall owners brought up public safely and obstruction policies enforced by the government authorities, which may cause the floor signages to be subjected for removal. They also remarked that the shop sign totems may be easily damaged from carts and moving operations in the market. It would be better for them to be hung on the light beams instead.

They suggested that the decorations could be hung on a cloth on a curtain rail so it could be retracted at night and pulled out in the daytime. However, they said we should avoid working with electricity for outside decorations as electrical wiring was difficult to manage and get permissions for.

Debrief

Chatting with stall owner

Updated Design

Based on this feedback, we designed a hanging signage instead and made sure that parts could be removable.

We then created a directory design.

To promote Pang Jai, we decided to host a co-creation workshop to create two dream catchers and banner using left over materials Mr. Ho had. This event was promoted on social media and posted around the area.

The product designer on our team created tote bags, as suggested by Mr. Ho, by silk screening the map of Pang Jai onto the fabrics.

Working with Mr. Ho to silkscreen the bags

Bag samples

Directory Feedback from Stall Owners

Jo and I wanted to visit the store owners again to confirm three things.

1. We wanted to confirm again if the stores and categorization system was correct.

2. We wanted to ask the owners about the design system. Because is so many fabrics and products in Pang Jai, we had chosen to use darker background with bright colours for our designs.

3. Third, we wanted to check ourselves if the directory was legible and easy to see when placed within the market.

After speaking with Mr. Ho, he walked us around the market to speak with all the store owners. Through this session, we realized that many of the stores were different than what we had initially observed, and almost all the stores had no visible signage to indicate who to speak to.

Speaking to Mr. Ho

Map after speaking with store owners

Measuring the directory placement

Workshops and Community Engagement

We aim to foster an interconnected relationship between the local residents and the community in Pang Jai. Our plan is to make Pang Jai more eye-catching from the inside out, making it easily recognizable to the public even though it is located under the bridge. Based on the concept of interwoven into one, our social design students decided to organize a fabric workshop to attract participants to learn about sheds and achieve the concept of co-creation.

We first asked Mr. Ho to collect old fabrics for us to prototype. In order to achieve the interweaving work, we tried to cut the old fabrics into strips and weave them on the wooden frame. As the strips of different colors and textures were interwoven, Together, it will become an installation art with rich colors and textures, achieving the effect of "into one".

Reflecting

The Pang Jai project aimed to revitalize market infrastructure to attract customers, enhance browsing experiences, and promote traditional Chinese culture. The collaborative project involved working with store owners and designers across multiple disciplines, including digital flyers, print, product design, and wayfinding. This teamwork led to innovative solutions by integrating diverse perspectives and skills throughout the research and design phases. The ultimate goal was to create design elements that not only serve functional purposes but also amplify Pang Jai's community spirit, contributing to its preservation and cultural significance within Hong Kong.

An Ongoing Project

Our project was approved for funding from the Government in 2024. Part of my team is currently working on with the store owners on the physical wayfinding. In the meantime, we have the prototype of the directory maps on display at the set locations to use, as well as the fabric workshop dream catcher set up at the front entrance. Last week (Upon writing this it is March 28th), my team put up some designs of the silkscreened bag on the walls in-between the stall sections. Mr. Ho said that a lot of people asked if they were for sale, so the team plans on making more for the vendors to sell themselves.
